channel.title: FTPOnline
channel.description: Technical information for developers and IT professionals from the FTP family of publications and conferences.

item.title: Enable OWA 2003
item.description: You can't use Outlook Web Access 2003 until you upgrade your mailbox servers.

item.title: Build Reporting Into Apps
item.description: Discover the alternatives to assess your reporting needs and get the right reporting engine.

item.title: Visual Studio Gets its Modeling Together
item.description: Borland announced a new design and modeling environment for the .NET Framework at VSLive! this week. Read the details in an exclusive interview with Tony de la Llama, Vice President/General Manager of Borland's Together Business Unit.

item.title: Boost Performance With Caching
item.description: Leverage ASP.NET's built-in page-caching and data-caching features to increase your Web applications' speed and scalability.

item.title: Create Mobile Database Applications
item.description: VS.NET 2003's enhanced support for mobile-application development lets you build enterprise-class Pocket PC and Windows CE apps that can access and update corporate databases.

item.title: Microsoft Commits to ALM
item.description: Microsoft is filling out its support for full application lifecycle management, including useful hooks in the .NET IDE for ISV products to fill in Microsoft's ALM gaps.

item.title: XML MetaData for Simplifying Web Development
item.description: Using XML to serve up your data provides business objects without properties, which speeds up code development and maintenance. Discover approaches that can reduce development time.

item.title: Optimize Performance
item.description: Vendors are competing to deliver information from all parts of the development life cycle to provide the Holy Grail in optimization: high performance in J2EE applications.

item.title: Merge XML Documents
item.description: Take advantage of the XMLDocument object to combine data files from multiple sources.

item.title: Luminaries Debate Issues, Opportunities
item.description: Ease of development and services integration took center stage as community technologists met in Java Pro's annual Technology Roundtable event at JavaOne. Read highlights of the lively discussion moderated by Sun's Simon Phipps.

item.title: New Strategy for Core Server OS
item.description: Microsoft has implemented a new strategy with Windows Server 2003: to release a core operating system that includes only essential server capabilities, and to supplement it with server add-ons.

item.title: Inside Visual Studio .NET 2003
item.description: VS.NET 2003 isn't the revolutionary product the first one was, but it includes many mobility and productivity features that you will quickly learn to appreciate.

item.title: Drive Java Development Through Testing
item.description: You must test your app not only to assure quality, but also to ensure it meets user requirements and behaves as expected. This is more difficult than it sounds. Find out how to start with a good testing regime before you code.

item.title: Gear Up for .NET 1.1 and Beyond
item.description: .NET's strict enforcement of version compatibility among application assemblies makes DLL Hell a thing of the past. However, you need to know the versioning ground rules to make your apps cope with multiple .NET versions.

item.title: Secure Your Organization's Mobile Devices
item.description: Don't let a stolen or lost mobile device result in a security breach. Take preventive steps to secure your company's laptops and PDAs.

item.title: Upgrade Legacy Apps to Web Services
item.description: When upgrading VB apps to .NET and Web services, you must address some implementation issues. Here are some tips to help you provide security, improve performance, and more.

item.title: Custom Web Dev
item.description: Download a sample app that gets you started using custom tag libraries.

item.title: Restrict Access to Web Resources
item.description: Often, you don't want your resources getting invoked directly by the outside world. Here are several ways to protect them gracefully.

item.title: Navigate the Web Services Hype Cycle
item.description: Understand the Web services hype cycle, so you know when and where to integrate the services.

item.title: Boost Performance When Parsing
item.description: External DTDs can be a performance nightmare if you don't know how to handle them. Try caching—it's a great way to handle DTDs when you're doing heavy-duty XML parsing.

item.title: Log Banner Impressions Asynchronously
item.description: Create an ASP.NET application using XML to track ad impressions on Web sites without losing performance.

item.title: Delve Into Exchange 2000 SP3
item.description: Exchange 2000 Service Pack 3 fixes bugs and increases security on your Exchange 2000 Server. Here's what you need to know if you plan to install it.

item.title: VSM Salary Survey
item.description: Compare your salary and job experiences with those of other Visual Studio developers.

item.title: Alliance of Alliances
item.description: In June, six wireless standards bodies formed the Open Mobile Alliance (OMA) to create a common platform for handset manufacturers and wireless providers. Will OMA succeed where others have failed?

item.title: Validate User Input with Filters
item.description: Filters can preprocess HTTP requests before they reach a servlet or JSP page, or responses before they go to a user. Learn how to use them to validate user input in the background.

item.title: Understanding the DOM
item.description: The Document Object Model API is an excellent way to read or manipulate XML documents, providing navigation through the documents' structure and complete editing functionality.

item.title: Remember User Preferences
item.description: Download a sample app that shows how you can retain user preference data across apps.

item.title: You Say You Want a Revolution?
item.description: Can XML turn our noble client/server applications into rich, message-driven networks where boundaries between process, server, and application cease to exist? After you find out, check out these related articles.

item.title: Pick Leaders Who Can Help You
item.description: Your leaders don't pick you. You pick them. Here's how to pick the right ones to lead you through the .NET vs. .NOT debates.

item.title: Debug VS.NET Applications
item.description: Using VS.NET's debugging tools is only half the battle—you also need to apply problem-solving techniques. Here's how.

item.title: Application, Heal Thyself
item.description: The first Java debuggers interfered with the execution of the program being debugged. The Java Platform Debugger Architecture fixes this problem.

item.title: The Future of XML in Wireless
item.description: Although some might argue that XML is too weighty for wireless devices, current and future standards efforts and technologies are paving the way for XML in the small arena.

item.title: Obfuscators Make .NET More Secure
item.description: Microsoft's decision not to ship an obfuscator product for .NET has opened the door for third-party companies.

item.title: Get a Handle on .NET Remoting
item.description: Find .NET remoting baffling? Download Juval Löwy's sample app to experiment with the different scenarios.

item.title: .NET vs. J2EE: A Third-Party View
item.description: Infragistics CEO and President Dean Guida talked with Visual Studio Magazine's Patrick Meader about how the .NET Framework stacks up against Java and J2EE. Plus, he gives the inside scoop on what you can do now about Web services, C#, VB.NET, and copy protection. And check out related reading from FTP.

item.title: Stop Writing Those #@%&!! Forms
item.description: Visual inheritance enforces consistency, shortens product cycle time, and drastically reduces an app's number of forms. Juval Löwy walks you through this powerful technique with a sample app.

item.title: Speech I/O for the Wireless Web
item.description: SALT provides a new speech technology approach to input and output on wireless devices.

item.title: Integrate Java Cryptography With Windows
item.description: Learn how to integrate the native Microsoft Windows certificate and key stores with Java security to reduce management overhead and improve certificate validity checking.

item.title: Snap Controls Together
item.description: .NETâ€™s full subclassing support lets you create new classes that inherit behavior from a base class. Learn to do this in VB.NET by building an owner-draw listbox, deriving your new class from the ListBox base class. Plus, check out these other essential articles on subclassing and control creation from VSM.

item.title: 4 Essential C# Tips
item.description: Here are Bill Wagner's favorite tips on using the C# language more effectively. He also has plenty of others to help you code better and faster with C#.

item.title: Build a Dynamic Module Subsystem
item.description: Learn an open architecture for building modules in an encapsulated package, and give your Java programs flexibility that will make life easier for you and for your applications' users. And click on these links for more information on JAR files, which you'll base your module architecture on.

item.title: Migrate Classic Apps to .NET
item.description: Should you move your apps to .NET? If so, which ones? The debate might be raging in your development shop, but in the meantime you can learn some good strategies for migrating your classic applications to .NET.

item.title: Tips on Making ASP.NET Design Decisions
item.description: User controls or server controls? Web services or remoting? Here's how to choose the right tool for the ASP.NET job. Plus, check out more tips from Jonathan Goodyear, as well as meaty discussions in our new ASP.NET forum.

item.title: How to Choose Web Services
item.description: Everyone's talking about building Web services, but that's only part of the picture. You need to know how to choose and consume them, too. How do you find a Web service that does what you want? How do you know if the provider is trustworthy? Get some answers, and check out our other recent Web services offerings.

item.title: Map Out Your Move to Windows .NET Server
item.description: Should you make the move to Windows .NET Server? Whether you're looking to launch Web service initiatives, or whether you're deploying Windows NT 4.0 vs. Windows 2000, your decision to migrate depends on how you use Windows now.

item.title: Eclipse Your IDE
item.description: Take advantage of the open-source Eclipse project, which provides a powerful, extensible Java development environment. You can also use it to build HTML, JSP, XML, or other language-development systems. And you can do even more with open source.

item.title: Tips on Making ASP.NET Design Decisions
item.description: User controls or server controls? Web services or remoting? Here's how to choose the right tool for the ASP.NET job. Plus, read even more ASP.NET advice from the experts.

item.title: Target Devices With XSL
item.description: The eXtensible Stylesheet Language can provide flexibility for a variety of client device support.

item.title: Use RPC-Style Web Services With J2EE
item.description: Use Web Services to build bridges between J2EE app components and other platforms. This free chapter from Sams' upcoming Teach Yourself J2EE in 21 Days shows you how.

item.title: Simplify Web Services With JAX-RPC
item.description: The Java API for XML-based remote procedure calls (JAX-RPC) simplifies building Web services. There's never been a better time to start implementing and calling SOAP-based Web services.
